Based on the provided configurations, here's the access scenario:

Users accessing Microsoft 365 services from compliant devices:

All users from Office1 can access Microsoft 365 services because the Conditional Access policy allows traffic from compliant devices and is assigned to all devices and the remote network linked to Office1.

Users from Office2 can also access Microsoft 365 services from compliant devices because they have the Global Secure Access client deployed, which ensures compliant network checks.

Users attempting to access Microsoft 365 services from noncompliant devices:

Users from both Office1 and Office2 will be blocked from accessing Microsoft 365 services, as the Conditional Access policy explicitly requires compliant devices for access.

This setup ensures that only compliant devices can access Microsoft 365 services across both offices, enforcing a strong security posture.

Compliant devices: Office1 only
Noncompliant devices: Office2 only

discussion.content:
Blob and File share.
For Azure File shares, the most granular level at which encryption can be applied is the share level, not the file level. Customer-managed keys (CMKs) can secure the entire file share, but not individual files within the share.

Blob
Account 

When you configure customer-managed keys for a storage account, Azure Storage wraps the root data encryption key for the account. By default, a storage account is encrypted with a key scoped to the entire storage account. When you define an encryption scope, you specify a key that may be scoped to a container or an individual blob.
